That's actually not what confirmation bias is. Confirmation bias is when people subconsciously seek out information that supports their point, not when they disregard other opinions. People typically aren't aware of confirmation bias operating; once they become aware of the other information, it's served its time and other factors come into play.

> [{quoted}](name=VeniVidiVelcro,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=Y2yKaEvE,comment-id=0001000000000001,timestamp=2015-11-25T14:38:54.035+0000)

People typically aren't aware of confirmation bias operating; once they become aware of the other information, it's served its time and other factors come into play.

Actually you are incorrect because your definition is slightly off. Confirmation bias does not have to be subconscious. Confirmation bias is defined as the tendency of one to seek/interpret data/information that confirms ones hypothesis, preconceptions or ideals.

Even when presented with data that opposes ones hypothesis, confirmation bias can still exist. This is because often people experiencing confirmation bias have the tendency to ignore, discredit or undervalue opposing arguments. What you are talking about is more along the lines of "expecting to be right". 

Example, I was developing a PID controller for a ball and plate system for our senior design project about a year ago. My theory was that I could look at a much easier example (ball and beam) and modify it to account for the additional 4 degrees of motion. Although one of my friends who was working on it said that it wouldn't be that simple. So I actively looked for evidence and models that would support my argument. When I found evidence showing otherwise, I took it into consideration but still thought my idea was correct but just didn't account for slippage. There was never a subconscious desire.

I think that the main issue is that although DfT is too strong on DoT champions, it's a little too weak on other champions, especially compared to the AD masteries. Trying to bring it in line for all champs lets them do more with it.

A better idea would be to add more masteries that are attractive to mages in general. 
Because Thunderlord's Decree is phenomenally "meh" and Deathfire Touch is meh on non-DoT mages, but has fantastic synergy on DoT mages. 

Everything else is pretty worthless on mages as a whole. So that leaves us with two choices, and neither choice feels particularly good unless you're a DoT mage (and even then you only have one actual good decision). An argument I've made against the new masteries since release is how restrictive they are in terms of choices and options.
